commit_message:
Add dummy test-app and test for it

- Add dummy app which able to spawn VM and wait for agent execution plan succeeded
- Add test for test-app which will run in CI
- Make create_environment test method more flexible(adding name parameter)

Change-Id: I374839735eda40cd954ce1d0736f8c97d0c82222
Partially-Implements: blueprint new-ci-tests-preparation

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import time import uuid import murano.tests.functional.engine.muranomanager as core class MuranoDeploymentTest(core.MuranoTestsCore): @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(MuranoDeploymentTest, cls).setUpClass() cls.linux = core.CONF.murano.linux_image cls.flavor = core.CONF.murano.standard_flavor cls._upload_dummy_app() @classmethod def tearDownClass(cls): super(MuranoDeploymentTest, cls).tearDownClass() cls.purge_environments() cls.purge_uploaded_packages() def test_app_deployment(self): post_body = { "instance": { "flavor": self.flavor, "image": self.linux, "assignFloatingIp": True, "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance", "id": str(uuid.uuid4()) }, "name": "testMurano" }, "name": "teMurano", "?": { "type": "io.murano.apps.test.UpdateExecutor", "id": str(uuid.uuid4()) } } environment_name = self.rand_name('dummyMurano') environment = self.create_environment(name=environment_name) session = self.create_session(environment) self.add_service(environment, post_body, session) self.deploy_environment(environment, session) self.wait_for_environment_deploy(environment)

commit_message:
Adds docstring for akanda.rug.main.main()

Inclusion of docstring as part of the method implementation for
better readability and maintainablity

Closes-bug: #1481458

Partially Implements: blueprint liberty-doc-updates

Change-Id: I474f99737e5a8a8f72a42ed2cd039386ffd8716e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/astara refs/changes/81/209281/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """This is the main entry point into the rug: Performs the following: a. parses the ak_cfg file and sets up log 'akanda-rug'. b. Brings up the External and Mgmt port c. Queue is setup to listen for events that includes i. notification-listener ii. metadata_proxy for changes to mgmt ip addr iii. various 'rug-api' events which are recieved through the mgmt ip interface d. Publishing changes(if any) to the listening ceilometer interface e. A pool of Worker threads are spawned that are scheduled to perform various tasks and these threads are scheduled to be (?What kind of scheduling is followed, RR or Prio based?) executed. f. A periodic heartbeat check is started to monitor the health of the scheduler and action initiated on timer expiry. g. This main process waits in an infinite loop process the various events heard on the Queue. Args: argv: Path to the Akanda Config file Returns: None Raises: None """ # TODO(rama) Error Handling to be added as part of the docstring # description

subject: Add spec for multiple-kmip-servers

commit_message:
Add spec for multiple-kmip-servers

Currently the kmip_plugin only supports one kmip device.
This blueprint proposes a new API for registering kmip
devices with barbican. Barbican can then use the kmip
device owned by the user's project to send requests.

Change-Id: I9e0b2998c58da45f481cd51797a0795cf669d743
Implements: blueprint multiple-kmip-servers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/98/194298/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================ Add ability to use multiple KMIP servers on a single barbican ================================================================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/multiple-kmip-servers Currently barbican only has one active plugin which means only one kmip server can be connected to barbican. This blueprint addresses that problem by creating an additional service available to the kmip_plugin to utilize the plugin with multiple kmip servers for multi-tenant functionality. Problem Description =================== When specifying the kmip plugin only a single kmip plugin may be attached to a single barbican. Specifying the secretstore plugin right now is currently done by manually editing the barbican-api.conf file to use the kmip plugin and specify all kmip_plugin specifications. This is fine if separate projects are okay with sharing a KMIP plugin. However, if multiple users have multiple kmip plugins then the only alternative is to bring up a new barbican for each new kmip server. This is not very scalable and is time consuming. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint offers a description of a new feature to use the kmip_plugin with multi-tenant functionality and introduce dynamic kmip server registration. A new controller will be built entitled 'kmipservers'. The api call will emulate current api calls with '/kmipservers' at the end of the url. The kmipservers controller will be used to manage kmip servers on barbican's backend. It will use **post** requests to tell Barbican it would like to register a new kmip device, **get** requests to get the kmip device currently registered with barbican, and **put** requests to modify the contents of a current kmip device. **Delete** requests will be used to remove a kmip device from barbican. A user will only have access and be able to modify the kmip device that it owns. It's ownership will be dependent on the user's project. An example of api calls will look something like this: POST: curl -X POST -H 'content-type:application/json' -H 'X-Project-Id:12345' -d '{"host": "100.99.98.97", "port": "5696"}' --data-binary @/home/chris/barbican.crt http://localhost:9311/v1/kmipservers PUT: curl -X PUT -H 'content-type:application/json' -H 'X-Project-Id:12345' -d '{"host": "97.98.99.100", "port": "5696"}' --data-binary @/home/chris/newbarbican.crt http://localhost:9311/v1/kmipservers GET: curl -X GET -H 'content-type:application/json' -H 'X-Project-Id:12345' http://localhost:9311/v1/kmipservers DELETE: curl -X DELETE 'content-type:application/json' -H 'X-Project-Id:12345' http://localhost:9311/v1/kmipservers In order for barbican to persist this data a new table will need to be created in the barbican mysql database. The table will have 4 columns: 'Project_Id','Host','Port', and 'Cert'. This ensures a kmip device is mapped to only one tenant. However, we don't want to alter the ability to be able to use the current kmip plugin as it is currently implemented. Under the kmip_plugin section of the configuration file there will be a new variable entitled 'multi_tenant'. The variable can be set to true or false. The variable will be used throughout the kmip code to detect if the kmip plugin is using multi-tenant functionality or not. .. code-block:: ini [kmip_plugin] multi_tenant=true #username = 'user' #password = 'password' host = localhost port = 5696 keyfile = '/home/mykey.key' certfile = '/home/mycrt.crt' ca_certs = '/home/mycacerts.crt' The following are diagrams detailing the flow for both the new API calls and requests made when multi_tenant is set to true. REGISTERING A KMIP DEVICE ------------------------- :: CLIENT BARBICAN DATABASE + + + | Register Kmip Device | Update Database | +---------------------------->+----------------------->| | | | | Return Success Status | Return success status | <----------------------------+<-----------------------+| | | | | | | + + + All API calls using the 'kmipservers' controller will have identical network flows as the diagram above. The difference will be if a client is registering a device, updating one. or deleting one. STORING A SECRET IN A KMIP DEVICE --------------------------------- :: CLIENT BARBICAN DATABASE + + + | Send secret to be stored | | +------------------------------>| Get KMIP location | | <-----------+----------->| | | | | | Store Secret | +--------+ | +----------------------------->| | | | | | KMIP | | Return Status | | | | <--------------------------------------------------------------+--------+ | | | | | | + + + All API calls to kmip devices through barbican will have an identical network flow as the one above. Alternatives ------------ There are different paths that could have been taken. * Store the KMIP server location as metadata. While this is possible and easy to implement it doesn't map the kmip device to a unique project. When creating new secrets barbican needs to know which kmip server to use. Storing the metadata on secrets only solves the access problem but not the registering problem. * Create a new custom plugin for multi-tenant kmip servers. It would be possible to create a custom plugin with a new service to handle on-boarding new kmip servers. However, the code would be the same as the kmip_secret_store plugin with the exception of a few different parts. It seems easier to put conditional checks in the current kmip code to check if multi_tenancy is enabled or not. Data model impact ----------------- No current data will be altered. This blueprint does suggest the creation of a new table: kmip_servers. It will have the following column description: :: +-------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +-------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | project_id | varchar(32) | NO | PRI | NULL | | | ip | varchar(15) | NO | | NULL | | | host | varchar(8) | NO | | NULL | | | cert | varchar(1229)| NO | | NULL | | +-----------------------------------------------------------+ Security impact --------------- There is a new security concern that a client might try to access a kmip plugin that they do not own. Measures will be added in addition to the already present oslo.config checks to ensure that users only access the kmip device they own. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ A new controller does add pressure on performance. However, it should not significantly impact performance of barbican. Adding a new kmip plugin is not a frequent operation. But adding it at runtime does reduce downtime of barbican significantly. The biggest performance impact is that if multi-tenancy is enabled, database queries are required to determine the correct kmip server to use. New checks will be written in the code to check if multi-tenant kmip functionality is turned on. These checks will be if statements and should not add significant processing time. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Christopher Solis (silos) Fernando Diaz (diazfj) Work Items ---------- 1. Create new 'kmipservers' controller for API 2. Create checks for if multi-tenant functionality is turned on 3. Create new database in barbican backend. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The unit tests for the KMIP plugin will change to reflect the addtion of multi tenant Kmip servers. New tests will have to be written in addition to making sure old tests do not fail. Documentation Impact ==================== Update the documentation to describe the additional functionality of the plugin. References ========== * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/multiple-kmip-servers

commit_message:
Glance images retain deleted properties

When you update an image with metadata by removing old properties and
add new properties; the update doesn't remove the old properties.

Instead of using upsert, use index operation for both create and update.
Here's the code diff with this patch using index operation which worked
for me.

Change-Id: Ida431531450e20984c276931f14ac4782397d389
Closes-Bug: #1480048
Co-Authored-By: Lakshmi N Sampath <lakshmi.sampath@hp.com>

commit_message:
Fix takes_config in try_catch_pass plugin

Current code results in exceptions being thrown with the message
TypeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__getitem__'.
This patch changes the imports and decorator declaration for this
plugin such that takes_config successfully passes in config.

Change-Id: Ic29dc7cf4556e4a42ac96cd1078f51f24626c063
Closes-bug: #1481922
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/79/209679/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from bandit.core import test_properties @test_properties.takes_config @test_properties.checks('ExceptHandler')

commit_message:
Adding hz-include directive

The angular provided ng-include is a useful directive but it creates a new
scope, which can be problematic. hz-include does the same thing but keeps
the scope the same.

Change-Id: I730c7c34c69967dc74e4cb7827aec89a0c0d2b75
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables

added_lines: /** * Copyright 2015 IBM Corp. * * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may * not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain * a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT * WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations * under the License. */ (function() { 'use strict'; /** * @ngDoc hz.framework.wizard.modal.service * @ngFactory * * @Description * The way angular-bootstrap modal work is a bit strange. * You have $modal in controller A which you can use to open to controller B. * You have $modalInstance in controller B spawn, which you can use to close or dismiss. * Upon closing, you can choose to pass information back to controller A. * The dismiss method does nothing. * * This is a problem because it requires us to define controller A for open. * And it also forces controller B to define close and dismiss. * The result is a bunch of controllers just to open a modal dialog. * * This service aims to simplify that by centralizing open, close, and dismiss. * It also provides some default options that you must override via init. * * @Example * * app.controller('tableController', function(modalService){ * modalService.init({ controller: 'wizardController' }).open(); * }); * * app.controller('wizardController', function($scope, $modalInstance, modalService){ * $scope.close = modalService.close($modalInstance); * $scope.cancel = modalService.cancel($modalInstance); * $scope.submit = function(){....}; * $scope.workflow = workflow({ * title: 'Title', * steps: [...] * }); * }); * */ angular .module('horizon.framework.widgets.wizard') .factory('horizon.framework.widgets.wizard.modal.service', modalService); modalService.$inject = ['$modal']; function modalService($modal) { var service = { open: open, close: close, cancel: cancel, init: init }; return service; /////////////////////////////// function init(options) { service.options = angular.extend(options, { controller: controller, controllerAs: 'ctrl', template: '<wizard></wizard>', backdrop: 'static', windowClass: 'modal-dialog-wizard', resolve: { modalService: self } }); return service; } function self() { return service; } function open() { $modal.open(service.options); } function close($modalInstance) { return function() { $modalInstance.close(); }; } function cancel($modalInstance) { return function() { $modalInstance.dismiss('cancel'); }; } } })();

commit_message:
Fix variable name in the second 'with' statement

Incorrect variable name is declared in
test_validate_key_cert_key_cant_read() method.

In the second 'with' statement, changed variable name
from keyf to certf.

Change-Id: I4d650fa22d333140f4f3309286bf74f730c8c7b8

commit_message:
Add "Delete port" to "Port binding ext attributes"

"Ports binding extended attributes" missing a whole description of
"Delete port" method. Please see http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html#port_binding-ext .

Change-Id: Ie3987209aa1d7ce3be63ec79a2abd08882d3c903
Closes-Bug: #1480406

commit_message:
Adds policy based routing for the amphora

1. Creates a new element for pyroute2
2. Adds this element to the amphora image
3. Updates the amphora REST interface to pass additional network information
4. Creates the policy based routes and rules on the amp during plug vip
5. Updates the REST API spec

Change-Id: Ibd622ec302cf78c12ae2bd5d76d012ab619939a6

commit_message:
Install arp spoofing protection flow after setting port tag

when ovs-agent set a tag for a port, it will first remove all
flows on this port, because it should guarantee that no drop_port
flow installed by port_dead remains, so arp spoofing protection
flow must be installed after it.

Closes-Bug: #1472452

Change-Id: I566d0fd93b39e81a34214f1a7a0a1decc9a169d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/25/199425/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent import ovs_neutron_agent \ as ovs_agent def _test_arp_spoofing(self, enable_prevent_arp_spoofing): self.agent.prevent_arp_spoofing = enable_prevent_arp_spoofing self.agent.int_br.db_list.return_value = [ {'name': 'fake_port_name', 'tag': []}] self.agent.local_vlan_map ={ 'fake_network': ovs_agent.LocalVLANMapping(1, None, None, 1)} need_binding_ports = [{'network_id': 'fake_network', 'vif_port': 1, 'device': 'fake_device', 'admin_state_up': True}] self.agent._bind_devices(need_binding_ports) if enable_prevent_arp_spoofing: self.assertTrue(self.agent.setup_arp_spoofing_protection.called) else: self.assertFalse(self.agent.setup_arp_spoofing_protection.called) def test_setup_arp_spoofing_protection(self): for enble in [True, False]: self._test_arp_spoofing(enble)
deleted_lines: def test_arp_spoofing_disabled(self): self.agent.prevent_arp_spoofing = False # all of this is required just to get to the part of # treat_devices_added_or_updated that checks the prevent_arp_spoofing # flag self.agent.treat_vif_port = mock.Mock() self.agent.get_vif_port_by_id = mock.Mock(return_value=FakeVif()) self.agent.plugin_rpc = mock.Mock() plist = [{a: a for a in ('port_id', 'network_id', 'network_type', 'physical_network', 'segmentation_id', 'admin_state_up', 'fixed_ips', 'device', 'device_owner')}] self.agent.plugin_rpc.get_devices_details_list.return_value = plist self.agent.treat_devices_added_or_updated([], False) self.assertFalse(self.agent.setup_arp_spoofing_protection.called)

commit_message:
Document configuring ironic-api behind mod_wsgi

This patch is documenting what the deployer should do to configure the
ironic-api service behind apache mod_wsgi.

Change-Id: I943e3c5f5f7344e0106e05662452a035c93c9a35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/91/207091/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Configuring ironic-api behind mod_wsgi -------------------------------------- Ironic comes with an example file for configuring the ``ironic-api`` service to run behind Apache with mod_wsgi. 1. Install the apache service:: Fedora/RHEL7/CentOS: sudo yum install httpd or sudo dnf install httpd Debian/Ubuntu: apt-get install apache2 2. Copy the ``etc/apache2/ironic`` file under the apache sites:: Fedora/RHEL7/CentOS: sudo cp etc/apache2/ironic /etc/httpd/conf.d/ironic.conf Debian/Ubuntu: sudo cp etc/apache2/ironic /etc/apache2/sites-available/ironic.conf 3. Edit the recently copied ``<apache-configuration-dir>/ironic.conf``: - Modify the ``WSGIDaemonProcess``, ``APACHE_RUN_USER`` and ``APACHE_RUN_GROUP`` directives to set the user and group values to a appropriate user on your server. - Modify the ``Directory`` directive to set the path to the Ironic API code. 4. Enable the apache ``ironic`` in site and reload:: Fedora/RHEL7/CentOS: sudo systemctl reload httpd Debian/Ubuntu: sudo a2ensite ironic sudo service apache2 reload .. note:: The file ironic/api/app.wsgi is installed with the rest of the ironic application code, and should not need to be modified.

commit_message:
Add functional tests for Barbican key manager wrapper

Creates the initial functional testing infrastructure for Castellan.
Functional tests are run using:
    tox -e functional
The Barbican wrapper tests require running local Barbican and Keystone
instances.
The functional testing config parameters can be overwritten by creating a
config file at /etc/castellan/castellan-functional.conf. A sample config
can be generated using:
    tox -e genconfig
The generated sample config can be found at etc/castellan/castellan-functional.conf

Implements: blueprint add-barbican-key-manager
Change-Id: Ideb9b1f01e51d85ff56575d8ab6ac970053a9604

commit_message:
Move multinode dvr job to neutron check list.

Next step in making them voting.  Will be watching
their failure rates as compared to the voting job.
Note: this is not intended as a long term change.
After collecting sufficient data, the job will
either be made voting or move back to the experimental
queue.

Change-Id: I05d1c5d1eea7a58ebf505bd4424525fd8ddc8aa4
Signed-off-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Put missing fields to validation schema

Field use_autoconfig is missing in the cluster templates and node groups
validation schema, so it should be added.

Change-Id: Idaf25374dc0a668d413a852c001cc36ec2313afd
Closes-bug: 1479035
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/44/207244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "use_autoconfig": { "type": ["boolean", "null"], }

commit_message:
Fixes the kafka publisher

The kafka publusher is not concurrency safe at all.
And the sample/event payload cannot be serialized correctly

To fix that:
* the code now is shared with the messaging one.
* the connection to kafka is done before sending messaging to not touch
  the queue
* use jsonutils to serialize samples

Change-Id: I3fb731d2eb33cbfba38c5165ce9874af89072e34
Closes-bug: #1479976

commit_message:
increase failure information for ip_regex test

It's basically completely impossible to understand why this test would
fail because there is not enough post mortem information. Probably an
address didn't allocate, but this is so stripped down you'd never know
that.

Add further dump on failure to make it possible to see what's happening.

Change-Id: I536f78c77df992dde5efd22b1d763715e33f0769
Related-Bug: #1481715

commit_message:
Stop using deprecated contextlib.nested

'contextlib.nested' was deprecated in py2.7 and removed in py3.
So, remove its usage for improvement of py 2/3 compatibility.

Change-Id: I49c71e696ffdeb61ebee308249667739e1b1b0db
Partially-Implements: bp py3-compatibility

subject: oslo-incubator apiclient.exceptions to keystoneclient.exceptions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-05 01:32:45.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/openstack/common/apiclient/exceptions.py', 'keystoneclient/exceptions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/62a12dfc5c93e97bee0b1a1666f7842a6b53d615', 'message': "oslo-incubator apiclient.exceptions to keystoneclient.exceptions

Applications are using exceptions out of
keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient.exceptions so it's part
of the public interface. But since it's from oslo-incubator it's
not considered stable. Since keystoneclient is all stable this
creates bad situation.

With this change, all the symbols out of apiclient.exceptions are
moved into keystoneclient.exceptions rather than the other way
around (keystoneclient.exceptions used to re-export all of
apiclient.exceptions). Now we're in control of the
apiclient.exceptions and keystoneclient.exceptions that
applications are using.

Conflicts:
        keystoneclient/exceptions.py

Change-Id: Ib3afa86b9d276f6a45d1ecd6f9157ee02ec8570d
"}]
commit_message:
oslo-incubator apiclient.exceptions to keystoneclient.exceptions

Applications are using exceptions out of
keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient.exceptions so it's part
of the public interface. But since it's from oslo-incubator it's
not considered stable. Since keystoneclient is all stable this
creates bad situation.

With this change, all the symbols out of apiclient.exceptions are
moved into keystoneclient.exceptions rather than the other way
around (keystoneclient.exceptions used to re-export all of
apiclient.exceptions). Now we're in control of the
apiclient.exceptions and keystoneclient.exceptions that
applications are using.

Conflicts:
        keystoneclient/exceptions.py

Change-Id: Ib3afa86b9d276f6a45d1ecd6f9157ee02ec8570d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/06/209306/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: class EnvironmentMuranoSanityClientTest(utils.CLIUtilsTestBase): """Sanity tests for testing actions with environment. Smoke test for the Murano CLI commands which checks basic actions with environment command like create, delete, rename etc. """ def test_environment_create(self): """Test scenario: 1) create environment 2) check that created environment exist """ # Create environment env_name, environment, env_list = \ self.create_murano_object('environment', 'TestMuranoSanityEnv') # Check that created environment exist self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) def test_environment_delete(self): """Test scenario: 1) create environment 2) check that created environment exist 3) delete environment """ # Create environment env_name, environment, env_list = \ self.create_murano_object('environment', 'TestMuranoSanityEnv') # Check that created environment exist self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) # Delete environment environment = self.delete_murano_object('environment', env_name, environment) env_list = self.listing('environment-list') self.assertNotIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertNotIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) def test_environment_rename(self): """Test scenario: 1) create environment 2) check that created environment exist 3) rename environment """ # Create environment env_name, environment, env_list = \ self.create_murano_object('environment', 'TestMuranoSanityEnv') # Check that created environment exist self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) # Rename environment new_env_name = self.generate_name('TestMuranoSEnv-env-rename') rename_params = "{0} {1}".format(env_name, new_env_name) new_environment = self.listing('environment-rename', params=rename_params) # Check that renamed environment exist new_env_list = self.listing('environment-list') self.assertIn(new_env_name, [env['Name'] for env in new_environment]) self.assertIn(new_env_name, [env['Name'] for env in new_env_list]) def test_table_struct_env_show(self): """Test scenario: 1) create environment 2) check that created environment exist 3) check structure of env_show object """ # Create environment env_name, environment, env_list = \ self.create_murano_object('environment', 'TestMuranoSanityEnv') # Check that created environment exist self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) env_show = self.listing('environment-show', params=env_name) # Check structure of env_show object self.assertEqual(['created', 'id', 'name', 'networking', 'status', 'tenant_id', 'updated', 'version'], map(lambda x: x['Property'], env_show)) def test_environment_show(self): """Test scenario: 1) create environment 2) check that created environment exist 3) check that env_name, ID, updated and created values exist in env_show object """ # Create environment env_name, environment, env_list = \ self.create_murano_object('environment', 'TestMuranoSanityEnv') # Check that created environment exist self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in environment]) self.assertIn(env_name, [env['Name'] for env in env_list]) env_show = self.listing('environment-show', params=env_name) # Get environment values updated = self.get_value('Updated', 'Name', env_name, environment) ID = self.get_value('ID', 'Name', env_name, environment) created = self.get_value('Created', 'Name', env_name, environment) self.assertIn(updated, map(lambda x: x['Value'], env_show)) self.assertIn(env_name, map(lambda x: x['Value'], env_show)) self.assertIn(ID, map(lambda x: x['Value'], env_show)) self.assertIn(created, map(lambda x: x['Value'], env_show))

commit_message:
Pseudo-folder name string should not contanins slash character

When create a pseudo-folder inside a container, the name of the pseudo-folder
should not contains slash character. Now only limit the slash character should
not be at the beginning or the end of the pseudo-folder name.

Change-Id: I3ba13e08e152747d43c7d734f81730305175e88f
Closes-Bug: #1479286
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/73/206973/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validators=[no_slash_validator])
deleted_lines: no_begin_or_end_slash = validators.RegexValidator(r'^[^\/](?u).+[^\/]$', _("Slash is not allowed at " "the beginning or end of " "your string."), code="nobeginorendslash") validators=[no_begin_or_end_slash])

commit_message:
Don't use sudo to install bundler gem for puppet jobs

There is no benefit to installing bundler using sudo, except to fix
path issues for the binary.  As a result, we should be sandboxing the
gem into GEM_HOME like other gems.

Change-Id: I93a92c6e5881b9ca8cc74fc376acde87edc0cd01
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I8401af5b228eeb24505e72baeabf3d33f4991665
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-05 20:29:54.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/edeb33b6b74f81ce649e2dedc6dc3d53da61e1f4', 'message': "devstack: Set VM MTU to 1400

to automatically avoid the most common instance of this problem by just

Change-Id: I8401af5b228eeb24505e72baeabf3d33f4991665
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
devstack: Set VM MTU to 1400

It's easy to run into MTU problems when using OVN if the MTU in your VMs
is the same as the underlying network.  In that case, packets will exceed
the MTU when the tunnel headers get added.  Update the devstack plugin
to automatically avoid the most common instance of this problem by just
hard coding the VM MTU to 1400.

Change-Id: I8401af5b228eeb24505e72baeabf3d33f4991665
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/59/209659/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # OVN uses tunnels between hypervisors to create virtual networks. These tunnels add # some headers to each packet. You may need to force a smaller MTU inside your # VMs to ensure that once the additional headers are added that the resulting # packets do not exceed the MTU of the underlying network. Otherwise, packets will # just get dropped. # # If you run into this problem, add the following dnsmasq config entry which will # tell VMs to use an MTU of 1400. # # $ echo "dhcp-option=26,1400" | sudo tee -a /etc/neutron/dnsmasq.conf # [[post-config|$Q_DHCP_CONF_FILE]] [DEFAULT] dnsmasq_config_file = /etc/neutron/dnsmasq.conf

commit_message:
Add tempauth middleware options

Tempauth middleware template included only example entries

This commit provides most options to configure tempauth middleware,
especialy an array of accounts/users hash which defines the authenticated
list available by tempauth

It's add by default the admin account/user
  user_admin_admin = admin .admin .reseller_admin

Change-Id: Ib67d7deeeb2f98a464d18813ae4569c28a04472a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/61/207161/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'swift::proxy::tempauth' do let :default_params do { 'account_user_list' => [ { 'user' => 'admin', 'account' => 'admin', 'key' => 'admin', 'groups' => [ 'admin', 'reseller_admin' ], }, ] } end let :params do default_params end let :pre_condition do 'class { "concat::setup": } concat { "/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf": }' end let :fragment_file do "/var/lib/puppet/concat/_etc_swift_proxy-server.conf/fragments/01_swift-proxy-swauth" end it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/[filter:tempauth]/) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/use = egg:swift#tempauth/) } it { is_expected.to_not contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/reseller_prefix/) } it { is_expected.to_not contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/token_life/) } it { is_expected.to_not contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/auth_prefix/) } it { is_expected.to_not contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/storage_url_scheme/) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content( /user_admin_admin = admin \.admin \.reseller_admin/ ) } context 'declaring two users' do let :params do { 'account_user_list' => [ { 'user' => 'admin', 'account' => 'admin', 'key' => 'admin', 'groups' => [ 'admin', 'reseller_admin' ], }, { 'user' => 'foo', 'account' => 'bar', 'key' => 'pass', 'groups' => [ 'reseller_admin' ], }, ] } end it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content( /user_admin_admin = admin \.admin \.reseller_admin/ ) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content( /user_bar_foo = pass \.reseller_admin/ ) } end context 'when undef params are set' do let :params do { 'reseller_prefix' => 'auth', 'token_life' => 81600, 'auth_prefix' => '/auth/', 'storage_url_scheme' => 'http', }.merge(default_params) end it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/reseller_prefix = AUTH/) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/token_life = 81600/) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/auth_prefix = \/auth\//) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/storage_url_scheme = http/) } describe "invalid params" do ['account_user_list', 'token_life', 'auth_prefix', 'storage_url_scheme'].each do |param| let :params do { param => 'foobar' }.merge(default_params) end it "invalid #{param} should fail" do expect { catalogue }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error) end end end end end

Yum returns 0 on partial failures, so the only way around

commit_message:
Fail on any yum install error during docker build

Yum returns 0 on partial failures, so the only way around
is to run separate `yum install` commands. This ensures
that the build fails early on, instead of at a later point,
wasting a deployer's time.

Change-Id: I4a85cd328c0d31c193c85f02c042ee5405666e5f
Partial-Bug: #1461052
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/11/209511/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
RUN rm -rf /etc/yum.repos.d/*;echo -e "[nailgun]
name=Nailgun Local Repo
baseurl=http://$(route -n | awk '/^0.0.0.0/ { print $2 }'):_PORT_/os/x86_64/
gpgcheck=0" > /etc/yum.repos.d/nailgun.repo; yum clean expire-cache; yum update -y; ln -s /etc/dnsmasq.conf /etc/cobbler.dnsmasq.conf; echo httpd cobbler dnsmasq xinetd tftp-server | xargs -n1 yum install -y --quiet
deleted_lines:

gpgcheck=0" > /etc/yum.repos.d/nailgun.repo; yum clean expire-cache; yum update -y; yum --quiet install -y httpd cobbler dnsmasq xinetd tftp-server; ln -s /etc/dnsmasq.conf /etc/cobbler.dnsmasq.conf

commit_message:
Add 'host' parameter to cinder.conf

'DEFAULT/host' parameter was added
to cinder.conf for cinder+ceph configuration

Upstream commit:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/209412/

Closes-Bug:#1474290

Change-Id: Icd1ee86a1d0fce13d3b5bb0acaa7ff644639c191

commit_message:
Delete default libvirt network definition

Remove default libvirt network due to possible using
the same network as VMs subnet in production cluster.

Co-Authored-By: Denis Egorenko <degorenko@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ic8720b37e924c4fbbe243f7a5ea9a94113d054fd
Closes-Bug: #1437410

added_lines: exec { 'destroy_libvirt_default_network': command => 'virsh net-destroy default', onlyif => 'virsh net-info default 2> /dev/null > /dev/null', path => [ '/bin', '/sbin', '/usr/bin', '/usr/sbin' ], } exec { 'undefine_libvirt_default_network': command => 'virsh net-undefine default', onlyif => 'virsh net-info default 2> /dev/null > /dev/null', path => [ '/bin', '/sbin', '/usr/bin', '/usr/sbin' ], } Service['libvirt'] -> Exec['destroy_libvirt_default_network'] -> Exec['undefine_libvirt_default_network']

commit_message:
Nodegroup can be created not only for GRE

Before: Nodegroup creation fails for non-GRE environmets with
an error
"403 Client Error: Forbidden (Node groups can only be created
when using Neutron GRE.)"

After: Nodegroup is created for non-GRE environmets with a
warning:
"WARNING: Node groups should be used for OpenStack environments
 that use an encapsulation protocol such as Neutron GRE."

Closes-Bug: #1472322
Change-Id: I56d70e7ca21b47f161dd85108c09ad54186f872e
Signed-off-by: Andrzej Skupien <askupien@mirantis.com>

Removes *.sql files from git ignore

*.sql files exist for db migration and they are
currently being ignored. This will exempt them from
the .gitignore file.

Closes-Bug: 1481741

commit_message:
Ironic: Configdrive extra data

This spec proposes adding support for operators to inject extra data
into the configuration drive for Ironic so that baremetal machines get
their instances configured correctly.

Change-Id: I6cd29b181acafb945756121bf030b44dd4023b58
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/79/173379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Ironic: Configdrive extra data ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ironic-configdrive-extra-data This spec proposes adding support for operators to inject extra data into the configuration drive for Ironic. Problem description =================== Operators of baremetal nodes sometimes need to pass extra information about their machines to get their instances configured correctly. A real use case example is passing information about the network interfaces of the baremetal machine and consistent naming them accordingly. Since the order in which network devices are named in Linux is based on the order in which they were found by the kernel as it booted. This type of configuration is already supported by ``os-net-config`` [`link <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147619/>`_] and can be used with heat to do the post-instance configuration of the baremetal node [`link <https://github.com/rdo-management/instack-undercloud/blob/master/heat-templates/ironic-deployment-os-net-config.yaml>`_]. Proposed change =============== The change consist in having the Nova Ironic driver to look for the information in the ``configdrive_metadata`` key in the extra attribute of the Ironic node and inject it into the configuration drive. The extra field in Ironic is a place where operators can put extra information about that baremetal machine. And the code in Nova that generates the configuration drive already contains an interface that allows the virt drivers to inject extra data into it. Alternatives ------------ Not a very clear alternative, since the configdrive is supposed to be used when a metadata service is not present in their environment. But, we could have a metadata service to serve the node this kinda of information. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ More data will inject in the configuration drive that potentially could impact on the speed to generate it. As far as I can tell and for the uses cases I've seem we are talking about few extra key/value pairs information being passed which doesn't cause any performance impact at all. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com> Other contributors: Work Items ---------- The Nova ironic driver already have a representation of the Ironic node when deploying it so all this work has to do is to make the driver check if the ``configdrive_metadata`` key is set in the Ironic node object and if so, gives the data to the interface that generates the configuration drive in Nova. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittests will be added to check if the extra data is being correctly handled. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation for the configuration drive in Ironic[1] will be updated. References ========== [1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/install-guide.html#enabling-the-configuration-drive-configdrive

commit_message:
Show 'is_deployable' instead of 'state' on the releases page

For current Fuel release always have 'available' state. It makes
no sense to show it, so 'is_deployable' is shown instead.

Change-Id: I64e9a2e5346491ee656163b7b1b5116794ea7dd7
Closes-Bug: #1477960

commit_message:
Revise db column constraint in Ironic ML2 integration spec

This patch revises the db column constraint, and is a reflection of
the gerrit code review [1].
The 'uuid' and 'address' columns should never be null, so the
constraint is changed from 'str_or_none' to 'str'.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/206232/6/ironic/db/sqlalchemy/models.py

Change-Id: I144736c1379503ae3f40223e7c7f2271d43790de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/29/209729/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: | uuid | str || address | str |
deleted_lines: | uuid | str_or_none || address | str_or_none |

commit_message:
Add info: License, Source, Bugs and Docs to README

Release tooling expects Source and Bug information to be in
a certain format.  This adds it to the README.rst so this
can be processed.

In addition, this also adds a section to README.rst making
Bug reporting clearer.

Change-Id: I738d45e5a5c68066957f1fc2eae526fda0a055e5
Closes-Bug: #1480062
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <email@daviey.com>

commit_message:
Add alias and node_roles to example v3 plugin network_roles

Added alias:
Enables visibility in api/clusters/ENVID/network_configuration/neutron
Default is empty.

Added node_roles:
Enables virtual_ips task to map node_roles to VIP assignment.
Default is primary-controller, controller.

Change-Id: Ia5acbe1f0246ac7a003620ebdece3b835faafb18
Closes-Bug: #1479873

commit_message:
Fix list creation

List creation '[x for i in 1,2,3,....]'  causes SyntaxError
in Python 3.

Add range() function for Python 3 compatibility.

Partially-Implements: bp py3-compatibility

Change-Id: Id7cc9b9c2e45f17e76bb5e698d7628a455452400

commit_message:
Scheduling VMs to servers taking into account the health of the platform.

This blueprint is about paying attention to the health of the server
and taking that into account at various layers in OpenStack,
such as when the scheduler selects a server as a target for running a VM.
Servers may be in various states of disrepair such as permanent subsystem
failure (fan failure), temporarily degraded (too hot), etc.
This blueprint is about creating a general framework to detect
these conditions, account for these conditions in a systematic way,
and to expose it to upper level SW such as the scheduler.

Change-Id: Id14731c05c9d679dcc7a10ad21b9cbd2ccb1b886
Implements: blueprint platform-health-aware-scheduling
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/64/174764/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================================= Scheduling VMs to servers taking into account the health of the platform. ========================================================================= The URL of launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/platform-health-aware-scheduling This feature aims to improve VMs' reliability and performance by avoiding scheduling to physical nodes which exhibit hardware problems. Servers may be in various states of disrepair such as: - permanent subsystem failure (for example: fan failure), or - temporary degradation (for example: overheating) The proposed solution is about creating a general framework to detect these conditions, account for them in a systematic way, and to expose platform health status information to nova scheduler. Problem description =================== Many factors accumulate to overall HW platform health status. Those factors are individual platform components. Contemporary servers are equipped with sensors which report health for individual components. Common categories of sensors are: Fan, Voltage and Temperature. Platform health information can be used in nova-scheduler to avoid scheduling on 'unhealthy' nodes, or the algorithm can prefer nodes with no evident signs of ill health while keeping 'unhealthy' nodes as a last resort by weighing it less. Use Cases ---------- Reliability and performance are among the most important attributes that end-users expect from their VMs and cloud operators from their infrastructure. Hence the VM scheduling process takes so many factors into account. The fact is that VM reliability and performance are directly associated with reliability and performance of underlying hardware infrastructure. The main use case behind this spec is that user expects VMs to be reliable. By allowing Nova to detect problems in hardware, via IPMI sensor readings, and avoiding scheduling on 'unhealthy' nodes this requirement can be met. An example is a case where servers have single or dual fan failures, or voltage or temperature sensor issues. Project Priority ----------------- Liberty release Proposed change =============== The idea is to leverage Utilization Aware Scheduler infrastructure and implement new 'platform health' monitor which would gather, at some interval, platform health status. On Compute Nodes Linux tool /usr/bin/ipmitool will be used for gathering locally HW sensors status via IPMI. New filter and weigher classes will be created for use in nova-scheduler. The filter logic will be that node for which all sensor in given category: Fan, Voltage, Temperature or Current will report critical will be filtered out. Node for which sensors will not be in Normal state will be assigned lower weight. Selection of such node for VM placement will be less probable. Information in logs will indicate why node is scored lower compared to healthy node. Subsequent blueprints could be created to extend scope of gathered platform health status. For exapmle, VMs relying heavily on RAM or disk health may benefit from not being instantiated on Compute Nodes which exhibit HDD/SSD errors, paging/swapping or high CPI IO wait. Alternatives ------------ Instead of using Utilization aware scheduling platform health data can be collected by Ceilometer and then Ceilometer API could be used in Nova to obtain platform health status. But this would provide dependency on Ceilometer in Nova and secondly a case would have to be handled when Ceilometer is not installed. Since scheduling is basic OpenStack function adding dependency on Ceilometer could negatively impact its stability. A wrapper for Linux 'ipmitool' could be re-used from Ceilometer. This would require moving IPMI releated code from Ceilometer to common code. Data model impact ----------------- No impact. Platform health data will be stored as key/value in nova DB, table compute_nodes, column metrics. REST API impact --------------- No impact. Security impact --------------- No impact. No new API created, PII information not stored nor transmitted, cryptography or hashing not involved. Notifications impact -------------------- No impact. Other end user impact --------------------- No impact Performance Impact ------------------ New monitor on Compute Node will be called once a minute to collect sensor data via IPMI interface. New platform health scheduler filter and platform health scheduler weigher will be called once per host for every instance being created. No additional DB queries are planned. Other deployer impact --------------------- - Linux ipmitool have to be working locally on Compute Node, two kernel modules need to loaded: ipmi_devintf, ipmi_si. - New platform health aware filter and weigher will be added to list of default filters/weighers. No imapct on deployer. Developer impact ---------------- No impact on other OpenStack developers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: andrzej-kuriata Work Items ---------- - New Utilization Aware Scheduler monitor to gather sensor status via IPMI (Linux ipmitool) - Platform health aware filter - Platform health aware weigher Dependencies ============ Platform health monitor depends on Linux ipmitool to get sensor data on local machine, which in turn requires 2 kernel modules: ipmi_devintf, ipmi_si Testing ======= The deliverables for this spec: UAS monitor, new filter and new weigher can be tested in isolation by unit tests. Scalability and performance testing in tempest may not be practical because potential issues would surface with large number of Compute Nodes. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation to be updated, add info about new filter and weigher: - OpenStack Configuration Reference - OpenStack Nova Developer Guide References ========== Blueprint for using Utilization Aware Scheduling as a vehicle for new metrics: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-useful-metrics

commit_message:
Add network ids to validation error messages

Previously, if a cluster had two networks with the same name
and there was an IP address conflict between them, you would
only see network names in the error message, which made it
difficult to identify what particular networks are causing
the conflict.

Added network ids to error messages about IP address conflicts.

Change-Id: I796b1a75cf850998ef4b5d7aff0404e09aa5ff4f

commit_message:
Add network ids to validation error messages

Previously, if a cluster had two networks with the same name
and there was an IP address conflict between them, you would
only see network names in the error message, which made it
difficult to identify what particular networks are causing
the conflict.

Added network ids to error messages about IP address conflicts.

Change-Id: I796b1a75cf850998ef4b5d7aff0404e09aa5ff4f

commit_message:
Add plugins dir to backup snapshot

- add plugins dir to backup by default.
- mend full backup of system dirs in order to include puppet
  and repos as well.

Closes-Bug: #1462439
Change-Id: Id8327a283c26574088db33e89bdaaa6c7a5e2d41

commit_message:
Extensible VIF plugging for Nova and Neutron

A means to add code to interface between Nova's hypervisor drivers
and Neutron's forwarding drivers by external parties.  This allows
Nova to discover code that implements new VIF types that future
drivers require, recognising that they may wish to perform
various actions in the pursuit of attaching a VIF to a port and
will in some circumstances want to use a new hypervisor
configuration.

It addresses both the use case where the hypervisor config changes
and the existing cases where other network elements must be
created to make the plug happen.  It also recognises that it is
gluing two components together and the code selected must align with
the needs of Nova (hypervisor driver and the driver's version) and
Neutron (the binding_type that Neutron is proposing).

Change-Id: I3d13e832461e6f78b0a0c36d21e250c716ab9b07
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/10/191210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Extensible VIF plugging ======================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/extensible-vifplug Define an explicit API for allowing operators to add 3rd party VIF plugging code, so that they can make use of Neutron drivers that require different plugging techniques without having to change files in core Nova. Problem description =================== Nova has a list of VIF plugging types (which varies by hypervisor driver) that corresponds to the VIF plugging types that Neutron and its various L2 drivers support. Adding to this requires changing core Nova code. When a new driver is written, and sometimes when an existing driver is changed, a new VIF type is occasionally required. This involves writing the Neutron driver code, committing it, getting it into public integration test, writing the Nova VIF plugging code and submitting it. The Nova VIF plugging code will likely turn up in an Openstack packaged distribution long after the need for it. Note that there used to be a VIF plugging interface that allowed 3rd party code to be integrated into Nova. It sucked, because it was at the wrong level, and the drivers in tree were conbined into a single VIF driver and the interface deprecated and removed. Nova developers explictly stated that they were not bound by the semantics of the interface, so it had no version proofing anyway, but at least while it existed there was an option to add VIF plugging code. Now nothing offers the same functionality. [1] is a different means to achieve a similar end, but this proposal also allows changes to be made to the hypervisor connection to a network. [1] will not address the next time that, for instance, someone wants to add the next network interface type (think vhostuser) to a hypervisor to work with their driver, as it doesn't permit the change of the hypervisor component of the binding, and only allows scripting before and after the plug. It also doesn't do much to address the duration of that scripting. Nor does this, but it does leave more flexibility. Use Cases ---------- This proposes that we define a specific (but versioned) interface for 3rd party, out of tree, Python code to be explicitly added to the list of avoilable VIF drivers. Thus, a network driver provider would be able to distribute their driver and the new VIF plugging type without necessarily changing core Nova code, or replacing the Nova package on the target machine. Project Priority ----------------- None. Proposed change =============== We propose an interface where Python classes that may live out of tree but on the Python path can be explictly named in the configuration file. They implement a specific interface that allows them to register their availability as VIF drivers. When selecting a VIF driver they are considered if they are compatible with the current hypervisor code in use. The configuration item to register a set of potential drivers is: vif_driver_extensions=python.class.path When this is found in the config file, if the class cannot be loaded then an error will be raised and Nova will exit. If the path exists, the class is instantiated and its 'register' function called. The register function returns a list of objects; each contains the following: - vif_plug_name: the VIF plugging type name - hypervisor: The name of the hypervisor driver class this serves - interface_version: a hypervisor specific version integer - methods specific to the hypervisor and interface version The class is build on a version-specific ABC from the hypervisor driver. If any duplicate name/hypervisor/version sets are found, the last listed one will be used from a file, and the last listed file's contents will override the earlier ones.. These are stored internally to nova-compute in a dict. When plugging occurs, a lookup occurs in this plugging type dict for name, hypervisor, and interface version of the hypervisor's VIF interface. If a match for binding_type and hypervisor is found, and an interface version that is supported by the hypervisor driver, the hypervisor will use the code referred to in the remaining keys to implement VIF plugging and unplugging. The interface used is hypervisor specific. It is assumed that the version will change if the functions required change or if their required inputs or outputs change. For instance, I might write a libvirt plug() that returns the section of libvirt config file I should use; in this case, the version of the interface would change if at any point the config file output requirements changed, or if the funtion changed name or arguments. The hypervisor driver must document all supported version interfaces. The interface allows code to be added, but addition has to be explicit; code will not be used because it resides on the system or the Python path, which means that simply installing a package containing code will not change the behaviour of Nova. When version updates occur, this can be done by first installing new hypervisor interface code in a new Python file, adding this class to the config file and restarting Nova, ensuring that the current and updated version of Nova will both be able to operate from the same config file with VIF plugging functional. Developers may distribute VIF plugging for multiple hypervisors or for multiple hypervisor interfaces in a single file, or add to the support with multiple files. We propose implementing this interface for libvirt, initially. The libvirt code will be refactored so that existing binding types are in class form, for consistency and because the current code is ugly. Alternatives ------------ None considered. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- This would increase the number of binding types offered to Neutron but would not change the API. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Small increase in bindnig time due to lookup in dict. Negligible. Other deployer impact --------------------- New config item. Slightly changed behaviour when upgrading, if and only if custom binding types are in use. If default behaviour is being used, then both can be ignored and there is no impact. Developer impact ---------------- Change in the way libvirt VIF drivers are written. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ijw-ubuntu Work Items ---------- Add config item Add loading of code Add libvirt v1 ABC Refactor libvirt code to ABC Add lookup to libvirt in advance of using usual code Dependencies ============ Recommend doing the binding_type negotiation first. Neutron will then be offered new types if they are installed and registered and not otherwise. Neutron's L2 driver has many options to behave sanely. Testing ======= Test registering a VIF type with the right version, wrong version, a syntax error, Test binding with a registered VIF driver. Test binding when multiple VIF drivers with the same match elements are loaded and ensure the last is used. Documentation Impact ==================== New config item. References ========== None. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

Dismiss changes dialog added on Support page

  - created new common method for noLeaveCheck in component mixin

Closes-Bug: #1441093

commit_message:
Polish the nova server profile unit test

This patch polishes the nova.server profile unit tests.

Change-Id: I02800050b3cf84d77a8349414612907a15c36681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/07/209807/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

test_do_leave_successful(self): nc = mock.Mock() profile = server.ServerProfile('os.nova.server', 's1', spec=self.spec) profile._nc = nc nc.server_metadata_get.return_value = {'FOO': 'BAR', 'cluster': 'CLS'} nc.server_metadata_update.return_value = 'Boom' obj = mock.Mock() obj.physical_id = 'FAKE_ID' obj.cluster_id = 'FAKE_CLUSTER_ID' res = profile.do_leave(obj) self.assertEqual('Boom', res) commit_message:
Fix incorrect cmdline parsing in BaseCLITest

str.split replaced with shlex.split in exec_command method.

BaseCLITest.exec_command fails if passed command line string
contains arguments with spaces, since str.split is used to
split arguments from string to argv list.

Change-Id: Ib5558d1787044399718f36d34e6d7a5e5e331fb3
Closes-Bug: #1482133
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/30/209830/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: return main_mod.main(argv=command.split())

commit_message:
Nodegroup can be created not only for GRE

Before: Nodegroup creation fails for non-GRE environmets with
an error:
"403 Client Error: Forbidden (Node groups can only be created
when using Neutron GRE.)"

After: Nodegroup is created for non-GRE environmets and the
following warning is logged:
"Node groups should be used for OpenStack environments that use
 an encapsulation protocol such as Neutron GRE."

Partial-Bug: #1472322
Change-Id: Iaa35fe16a02d73ced7a87a0c7ac2d167d1e77740
Signed-off-by: Andrzej Skupien <askupien@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 870a5a09c1041db42541c233a56e6f633c30d0f2)

commit_message:
Remove --env from node provision and deploy

This argument does nothing in this command, environment id is taken from
the node.

Change-Id: I9595b733b9bd7da13ac874ac2b199db363963f4f
Closes-Bug: #1474202

commit_message:
Add devstackgaterc to manage gate tests

In order to be able to manage the tests to run at the gate, add
devstackgaterc with the regex indicating the tests to run.

The regex generated runs the same set of tests as those running at the
gate currently, which are:

 * network API tests
 * scenario tests

blueprint midonet-devstackgaterc

Change-Id: Icb7402fffaf6523051a36c98d121007a223586c9
(cherry picked from commit 0b6aa65)

commit_message:
Add section for security group with neutron

Add new section in Operation-Guide that explain the
security group settings using neutron command.

Change-Id: Ide7a85db6dba1f60519bd7a4c3ef2eff801ade4b
Closes-Bug: #1408912
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/01/205801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
Setting with nova command From the command line, you can get a list of security groups for the project you're acting in using the nova command: $ nova secgroup-list To view the details of the "open" security group: $ nova secgroup-list-rules open These rules are all "allow" type rules, as the default is deny. The first column is the IP protocol (one of icmp, tcp, or udp), and the second and third columns specify the affected port range. The fourth column specifies the IP range in CIDR format. This example shows the full port range for all protocols allowed from all IPs. When adding a new security group, you should pick a descriptive but brief name. This name shows up in brief descriptions of the instances that use it where the longer description field often does not. Seeing that an instance is using security group http is much easier to understand than bobs_group or secgrp1. As an example, let's create a security group that allows web traffic anywhere on the Internet. We'll call this group global_http, which is clear and reasonably concise, encapsulating what is allowed and from where. From the command line, do: $ nova secgroup-create \ global_http "allow web traffic from the Internet" This creates the empty security group. To make it do what we want, we need to add some rules: $ nova secgroup-add-rule <secgroup> <ip-proto> <from-port> <to-port> <cidr> Note that the arguments are positional, and the from-port and to-port arguments specify the allowed local port range connections. These arguments are not indicating source and destination ports of the connection. More complex rule sets can be built up through multiple invocations of nova secgroup-add-rule. For example, if you want to pass both http and https traffic, do this: $ nova secgroup-add-rule global_http tcp 443 443 0.0.0.0/0 Despite only outputting the newly added rule, this operation is additive: $ nova secgroup-list-rules global_http The inverse operation is called secgroup-delete-rule, using the same format. Whole security groups can be removed with secgroup-delete. To create security group rules for a cluster of instances, you want to use SourceGroups. SourceGroups are a special dynamic way of defining the CIDR of allowed sources. The user specifies a SourceGroup (security group name) and then all the users' other instances using the specified SourceGroup are selected dynamically. This dynamic selection alleviates the need for individual rules to allow each new member of the cluster. The code is structured like this: nova secgroup-add-group-rule <secgroup> <source-group> <ip-proto> <from-port> <to-port>. An example usage is shown here: $ nova secgroup-add-group-rule cluster global-http tcp 22 22 The "cluster" rule allows SSH access from any other instance that uses the global-http group.
Setting with neutron command If your environment is using Neutron, you can configure security groups setting using neutron command. You can get a list of security groups for the project you're acting in using follwing command: $ neutron security-group-list +--------------------------------------+---------+-------------+ | id | name | description | +--------------------------------------+---------+-------------+ | 6777138a-deb7-4f10-8236-6400e7aff5b0 | default | default | | 750acb39-d69b-4ea0-a62d-b56101166b01 | open | all ports | +--------------------------------------+---------+-------------+ To view the details of the "open" security group: $ neutron security-group-show open +----------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +----------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | description | all ports | | id | 750acb39-d69b-4ea0-a62d-b56101166b01 | | name | open | | security_group_rules | {"remote_group_id": null, "direction": "egress", "remote_ip_prefix": null, "protocol": null, "tenant_id": "607ec981611a4839b7b06f6dfa81317d", "port_range_max": null, "security_group_id": "750acb39-d69b-4e0-a62d-b56101166b01", "port_range_min": null, "ethertype": "IPv4", "id": "361a1b62-95dd-46e1-8639-c3b2000aab60"} | | | {"remote_group_id": null, "direction": "ingress", "remote_ip_prefix": "0.0.0.0/0", "protocol": "udp", "tenant_id": "341f49145ec7445192dc3c2abc33500d", "port_range_max": 65535, "security_group_id": "750acb9-d69b-4ea0-a62d-b56101166b01", "port_range_min": 1, "ethertype": "IPv4", "id": "496ba8b7-d96e-4655-920f-068a3d4ddc36"} | | | {"remote_group_id": null, "direction": "ingress", "remote_ip_prefix": "0.0.0.0/0", "protocol": "icmp", "tenant_id": "341f49145ec7445192dc3c2abc33500d",
